text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English 
with Jennifer. It won't surprise you

to know that I believe everyone should 
know at least a little bit of grammar.

Grammar is all about patterns, and following the 
usual patterns helps us have clear communication.

What's the difference between a word and a 
phrase? A word is a single piece of language:

cat, girl, sing, singing, beautiful, 
beautifully, to, from, here.

A phrase is a group of two or 
more words: a beautiful girl,
sing beautifully.
for me.

Phrases aren't complete ideas. They 
don't have both a subject and a verb.

Sometimes we speak in phrases if the rest is 
understood. What do you see? A pretty cat.

There are different kinds of 
phrases. We can have a noun phrase,
a verb phrase,
a prepositional phrase,
an infinitive phrase,
a gerund phrase.

There are other kinds of phrases, but 
remember that no phrase is a complete idea.

A clause is a group of words with a subject 
and a verb. Clauses can be short or long:
The girls sang.
Songs entertain us.

Birds are common pets in many 
countries around the world.
Inside a clause, you may find a number of phrases.

Some clauses can stand alone. We call them 
independent clauses. An independent clause

is a simple sentence. Other 
clauses are dependent clauses.

We have to join these dependent clauses with an 
independent clause to form a complete sentence.

If you don't know what to do 
with this, I can show you.

Try two short quizzes. Here's the first. Can 
you identify the phrases and the clauses?
Here are the phrases.

And here are the clauses. Notice how the 
clauses each have a subject and a verb.
Here's the second quiz. Look at four clauses.

Which of them are independent clauses Which of 
them can stand alone as a complete sentence?

A and D are independent clauses. They 
can stand alone as complete sentences.

It's a traditional Chinese 
dance. I wanted to learn.

B and C are dependent clauses. 
These are adverb clauses.

They have to join with independent 
clauses to form a complete sentence.

That's all for now. I hope this 
was helpful. Please like the video.
As always, thanks for watching and happy studies!

Everyone, visit me on Patreon. You can join to 
support my online work, get live lessons and bonus

videos, and some of you may even want a monthly 
one-on-one video call. Follow me on Facebook,

Twitter, and Instagram. Why not join me on 
Patreon? And don't forget to subscribe on YouTube.
